comment.author: 39393844@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Well I'll admit I hadn't a clue, but it transpires he was the Registrar General for Ireland, who seems to have had a love for population data and medical statistics from decadic Census. In the All Ireland Review, 1902, the following quote is attributed to him (and not with much admiration either): 
Dr. Grimshaw sums up the results of his comparisons between 1841 and 1890 in the
following terms: "I have shown, by taking many tests, and applying them each in turn, that Ireland has advanced in the arts of civilization and in material prosperity. Whether she has done so at an equal rate with other countries is a question I have not ventured to discuss ; but many valuable statistics necessary for its solution could be collected and compared. Possibly she might have advanced more than she has done, but when we consider the mighty collapse that took place at the commencement of the past half century, which began in the days of the great famine of 1846, '47, and '48, it may be that Ireland has advanced more rapidly and recovered from a condition of almost total wreck more completely than any other country would have done or ever has done."

... well that's nice.

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content:
Dreadful architecture that new Passport Office building !
Consider those in the Corpo who consistently voted for the destruction of Dublin's fine Victorian and Georgian heritage. Always the same names keep cropping up of which one of them is an ex-Taoiseach.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/39393844@N04] Good God, man, what's a decadic Census?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39393844@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Oh well now you have me. I thought it was a census every 10 years (1821, 1831...) but maybe I just made that up in my head, which is quite likely. 

Can I squeeze in one more piece of information on Dr Grimshaw? Proceedings of the RIA 1864 list him as a member of the Academy (since 1842), giving his address as 13 Molesworth St... which one is that? :)

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: Hmmm....I'd have said 'decadian'

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/39393844@N04] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/23885771@N03] Tried my Google Test (how many results for either), but results inconclusive because it was including Acadian Census...

And [http://www.flickr.com/photos/39393844@N04] Thérapie Salon on the corner of Molesworth Street and Sth Frederick Street is 8-9, so 13 would be somewhere in or just after the Passport Office as you head towards the Library...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39393844@N04
comment._content:
Thanks re numbering. So probably the building after the one with the gable end, where the boarding starts. That makes sense, with where the plaque is now. 

Re decadic/decadian/decadent... checked no less a source than E Margaret Crawford who refers to "decennial censuses". Have no idea where I got decadic from!

Isn't it funny where a picture of Molesworth St gets us?! :D
